III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation All the other staff are always on their phone and ignore youth and
don’t do things that they ask them to do.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. He reported hearing about the allegations from the
Licensing Consultant. He also reported there are three youths
(Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C) on the unit. He reported a new
policy is in the process of being developed but that all staff have
been made aware that the phone policy (Staff Behavior policy) will
be enforced fully at this time.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. Youth A reported Staff 3 uses the cell phone but doesn’t
make calls, while Staff 18 and Staff 19 both make cell phone calls
when working. Youth A reported Staff 1 was scrolling on a cell
phone while working 2 days ago. Youth A reported Staff 2 will
scroll on the cell phone all the time while Staff 5 will also use the
cell phone when working. Youth A reported Supervisor 3 has told
staff to go behind the camera view so Administrator 1 can’t see
the staff using the cell phone. Youth A was unable to identify any
specific details about staff using their cell phones when working
other than to state “it’s just a variety of different times”. Regarding
staff not responding to youth when youth ask for help, Youth A
reported not being able to remember dates or times that Youth A
has observed this behavior from staff. Youth A reported one
specific incident but could not remember the staff’s name nor the
name of the other youth present. Youth A reported the youth who
witnessed the incident left the facility sometime in the past. Youth
A reported asking staff to open the bathroom but having the
unknown staff ignore Youth A’s request.
2

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. Youth B denied staff are using their cell phones when
staff are supervising youth. Youth B reported staff place their cell
phones in lockers as required. Youth B also reported staff are
attentive to youth and help the youth all the time. Youth B reported
staff provide supervision and will get supplies when needed.
Youth B reported there has never been a time, staff have not been
supportive towards her.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. Youth C reported staff are not using their cell phones
when working and will place the cell phone in the locker as
required. Youth C reported any youth who reports staff are not
helpful are “lying” because staff are always helping youth. Youth C
reported staff supervise youth and there has been no issues with
staff.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. He reported working the overnight shift and will hold
staff accountable to keep their cell phones in the locker or their
car. He reported if he catches a staff using a phone while working,
he will issue a warning and if caught again, he will issue a “write-
up”. Supervisor 1 reported staff are supervising and attentive to
the youth. He denied staff are not providing needs that the youth
are requesting.
Staff 1 and Staff 3 were interviewed individually face-to-face
at the facility on 5/1/2025. Both reported staff were using their
phone more in the past but since the new phone policy, staff are
not using their phones for personal reasons when supervising
youth. They reported staff will get coverage and step out if
needing to make a personal phone call. They reported staff might
use a phone if the walkie-talkie is not working and they need to
communicate with a supervisor. They reported this happens at
times and staff need to communicate as part of the supervision of
youth. They reported cell phones are to be placed in a locker.
They reported not being aware of any staff not helping nor
providing a need for youth and staff are very attentive to meeting
youth’s needs. They reported the youth may need to wait at times
because of a situation but never are youth denied items.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2025.
She denied observing any staff using their cell phone when
working. Staff 2 reported someone is lying about staff helping
youth because staff will follow through with a youth’s request for
help or items.
3

Supervisor 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2025. He reported there have been staff using their cell
phones and these staff have been “written up”, or sent home, or
terminated. He reported the cell phone policy is that staff are not
to use their cell phones in front of youth, but this policy has
changed. The new policy is staff lock their phone away or leave it
in the car. He reported when catching a staff member using their
phone, he will send them home or write them up. He reported
having a zero tolerance for staff using a cell phone when working.
He reported staff overall are following the new policy. Supervisor 2
reported not hearing of any youth complain about staff not getting
supplies or meeting the youth’s needs. He reported staff are
receiving guidance weekly (team meetings) on staff’s response to
youth’s needs.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2025.
She reported staff are still using their personal cell phones and not
paying attention to the youth. She was unable to provide any
specific details about this claim but settled on “all the time”. She
reported the facility has a new phone policy involving staff are not
to have their personal phone with them when working. She
reported supervisors are now enforcing the policy. Staff 4 reported
staff will get upset with youth at times and don’t respond to the
youth’s request timely. Staff 4 was unable to provide any specific
details about this claim of staff being upset.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via phone on 5/13/2025. He
denied ever telling staff to go out of camera sight to use their
phone. He reported with the new phone policy staff are to lock up
their phones in the lockers and he will “write-up” staff using their
phones for personal issues when they are supervising youth. He
reported never observing a staff ignore a youth when the youth is
requesting something from the staff. He reported staff are
attentive to youth especially when the youth is requesting
something like having the bathroom unlocked.
Supervisor 4 was interviewed via phone on 5/13/2025. She
reported that the staff on her shift follow the phone policy and will
“write-up” any staff that doesn’t. She also reported it’s a “total lie”
that staff are not attentive to youth’s requests and youth are
demanding to have the request filled immediately. She reported
staff work very diligently to meet the requests from youth.
Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 11, Staff 13, Staff 14, Staff 15, Staff 16,
and Staff 17 were interviewed via phone, separately on
4

5/13/2025. They all reported not witnessing staff currently on their
phone and staff are following the phone policy. They all reported
that staff are attentive to youth’s needs when youth request
something from staff. They denied staff withholding anything and
they reported sometimes youth get inpatient and want something
right away even if a staff is in the middle of helping another youth.
They reported sometimes the youth will get upset if staff are
unable to respond immediately to the youth’s request, but staff try
to verbally de-escalate the youth.
Staff 7, Staff 9, Staff 10, and Staff 12 were interviewed via
phone, separately on 5/13/2025. They reported prior to the new
policy, some staff were using their phones during working hours
such as helping youth with homework. They described at times
the phones were an issue with a few of the staff but since the new
policy was put into place things have changed. They reported staff
only use their phones to call the supervisor if other forms of
communication are not available. They all reported no staff are
ignoring youth, but youth get very demanding if the need is not
met immediately. None of them were able to recall observing any
staff put off or ignore a youth when the youth is requesting
something or some help.
Staff 18 and Staff 19 were interviewed via phone, separately
on 5/13/2025. Both reported working 3rd shift and not observing
any staff on their phone doing personal business. They reported
the new phone policy requires staff to not have their phones on
the “floor” during working hours and both believe the youth may try
to grab a staff member’s phone. Both reported never observing
staff not meeting a youth’s needs and they are required to open
the bathroom for safety reasons and the bathrooms are locked at
night.
Staff 20 was interviewed via phone on 5/23/2025. She reported
not using her phone at work and believes Youth A may have
made this claim because of Youth A’s dislike for Staff 20. Staff 20
reported she will spend most of the time at work interacting with
different youth, but Youth A has refused to interact with Staff 20
because Staff 20 has redirected Youth A and Youth A doesn’t take
redirection well. Staff 20 also reported knowing of the new phone
policy and the enforcement of this policy. She reported staff are
attentive to youth’s needs and are very supportive of the youth.
5

Documents Reviewed:
Vista Maria Residential Programs Client Supervision dated
3/2021. This document outlines the responsibilities of
staff/supervisor to supervise the youth in the program. It is stated
that staff who are responsible for youth supervision should
maintain a line of sight at all times.
Vista Maria Residential Programs Employee Behavior dated
4/2021. This document outlines the guiding principles of
acceptable and unacceptable employee behavior. It is stated that
employees are expected to conduct themselves in a positive,
professional and respectful manner at all times. Staff are to treat
youth in a manner which supports the program’s trauma informed
practices. It is also stated that personal cell phone use is only
permitted during scheduled breaks and are not allowed while in
the presence of youth in any residential program.
Vista Maria Seeking Solutions to Resident Rights Concerns
dated 4/15/25 authored by Youth A. It is documented by Youth A
that Staff 20 was on her personal phone and ignored Youth A. It is
documented on this form that this was investigated by
Administrator 1 who documented his findings. “Three youth were
interviewed and two staff were interviewed. Camera footage of the
alleged phone use was also reviewed, and Administrator 1 was
unable to confirm the allegations of phone use.
Video Review:
The facility does have camera’s, but none were reviewed because
there was no specific dates or times indicated by the complainant
of phone use or staff refusing to meet a youth’s request.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is an
older building that has evidence of being in the process of having
repairs to the walls. They have plywood covering holes in the
walls until the scheduled repairs can be completed. Administrator
1 reported repairs have been scheduled. The facility is furnished
appropriately, especially in the bedroom areas and the plumbing is
in working order.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidenced by interviews with
staff, youth, and documents reviews. Evidence indicates staff may
have been using their phones for personal issues, but the facility
6

has addressed this issue with the new enforcement of the phone
policy and the purchasing of phone lockers. There is also no
evidence that staff were not providing for youth’s needs when
requested by a youth.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in making sure the phone policy
is clear and concise, so staff are able to follow the policy. The
facility should also provide another form of communication
between staff such as walkie-talkies to ensure staff can call for
assistance or get questions answered if no phones are to be on
their person when supervising.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
